image.altText: Map of temperatures anomalies in southern parts of South America

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Scientists in disbelief as temperatures soar to 37C in South America in the middle of winter

title.children: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner Kershaw rubbishes suggestions he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

image.altText: Donald Trump, holding an umbrella in the rain, speaks to reporters at an airport.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty after being indicted on charges related to his conduct in the 2020 presidential election. Follow our live updates.

title.children: Trump claims he's being 'persecuted' after pleading not guilty to 2020 election interference charges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi Brad, thanks for your coverage. When do we expect the six co-conspirators to be charged? - Tim. There’s been no real indication from the prosecution about if and when that will happen. But given the indictment essentially accuses the “co-conspirators” of serious criminal behaviour, a lot of people are asking why they haven’t been charged. Some legal experts think it could be that the prosecutor wants to speed things up ahead of next year’s election. Indicting seven people, instead of one, would make things far more complex and inevitably slow down the court process. Others think the threat of charges could encourage the “co-conspirators” to try to strike a deal with prosecutors. That could mean co-operating with them in their efforts to prosecute Trump. That’s a long shot, though, given these people have stayed so loyal to Trump so far. Some have explicitly said they will remain so. For example, a lawyer for John Eastman, who is believed to be “Co-conspirator 2”, has put out a statement saying his client was not involved in any plea bargaining and “if Dr Eastman is indicted, he will go to trial”.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: When will Trump's six alleged co-conspirators be charged?

children.content: Hi Brad, thanks for your coverage. When do we expect the six co-conspirators to be charged?
- Tim
There’s been no real indication from the prosecution about if and when that will happen.
But given the indictment essentially accuses the “co-conspirators” of serious criminal behaviour, a lot of people are asking why they haven’t been charged.
Some legal experts think it could be that the prosecutor wants to speed things up ahead of next year’s election.
Indicting seven people, instead of one, would make things far more complex and inevitably slow down the court process.
Others think the threat of charges could encourage the “co-conspirators” to try to strike a deal with prosecutors. That could mean co-operating with them in their efforts to prosecute Trump.
That’s a long shot, though, given these people have stayed so loyal to Trump so far. Some have explicitly said they will remain so.

For example, a lawyer for John Eastman, who is believed to be “Co-conspirator 2”, has put out a statement saying his client was not involved in any plea bargaining and “if Dr Eastman is indicted, he will go to trial”.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The former US president has been posting on social media quite a bit this morning. Among his comments, Mr Trump said that he'd had a "very good day" — aside from the fact that he had to "fly to a filthy, dirty, falling apart and very unsafe Washington, DC". Earlier in the morning, he joked that he needed "one more indictment" to ensure his election.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump: 'I NEED ONE MORE INDICTMENT TO ENSURE MY ELECTION!'

children.content: The former US president has been posting on social media quite a bit this morning.
Among his comments, Mr Trump said that he'd had a "very good day" — aside from the fact that he had to "fly to a filthy, dirty, falling apart and very unsafe Washington, DC".
Earlier in the morning, he joked that he needed "one more indictment" to ensure his election.

props.alt: A post on truth social from former US president donald trump.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A lawyer who supported Donald Trump's attempts to overturn his 2020 election defeat has been charged with illegally accessing voting machines in Michigan, just hours before the former president was due to appear court. Stefanie Lambert Junttila, who along with other Trump allies tried to reverse Trump's defeat to US President Joe Biden in Michigan, was charged with accessing, tampering with and undue possession of voting machines in the state. Ms Lambert is the third person charged in Michigan this week after a special prosecutor in that state reviewed allegations that Trump allies illegally accessed voting machines after the 2020 election. Two other Republicans, former Michigan attorney general candidate Matt DePerno, and Daire Rendon, a former state representative, made their initial court appearances on Tuesday in connection with the case. All three were named last year by the state's attorney general in an investigation of a scheme to access voting tabulators.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump ally charged over vote machine tampering hours before former president's court appearance

image.altText: Suncorp accepts a $4.9 billion offer from ANZ for its banking business

items.synopsis: Australia's competition watchdog has rejected ANZ's proposed takeover of Suncorp's bank, while local traders await the RBA's latest statement on monetary policy. Follow live.

title.children: ACCC rejects ANZ's $4.9b takeover of Suncorp, Amazon earnings surge, ASX flatlines at open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The banks at the centre of the ACCC 's decision to block a takeover deal, ANZ and Suncorp, have issued statements to the stock exchange. ANZ shares are up 0.6 per cent in early trade. Boss Shayne Elliott said ANZ is "naturally disappointed and disagree with the ACCC's decision". "We believe the acquisition will improve competition, which will benefit Australian consumers, particularly in Queensland," Mr Elliott said in the ASX statement. ANZ also noted that decisions by the ACCC could be reviewed by the Australian Competition Tribunal. And in the meantime, it "continues its preparations for the integration of Suncorp Bank into ANZ". Meanwhile, Suncorp shares are now down 1.9 per cent after the news. Suncorp chair Christine McLoughlin says the bank is "surprised and disappointed" and would "fully support" ANZ if it referred the decision to the Australian Competition Tribunal. "…we believe the Tribunal will accept the merits of our case," she said. Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has also noted the decision, saying the government "respects the independence of the ACCC and does not intend to comment further on the decision or the future of the proposal", but noted that there is the option for the banks to take the decision to the Tribunal or Federal Court. So… watch this space!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ, Suncorp respond to blocked takeover deal

"…we believe the Tribunal will accept the merits of our case,"

So… watch this space!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're just minutes into the local session and so far the benchmark index is fairly flat. While more than 130 of the top 200 stocks are in the red, there's some positive moves for the big banks and miners, which are helping to limit the losses overall. Of particular note after news that the ACCC has blocked a $4.9 billion deal between the pair, ANZ shares are up around 0.4 per cent, outperforming their peers, while Suncorp investors seem disappointed, with shares down 2.3 per cent .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX flatlining in early trade, Suncorp falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw is facing tough questions about his links to former NSW Police Commissioner Mick Fuller - who went on to be a partner at consulting firm PwC and lead a lucrative $794,000 contract to review policing in the ACT. In his opening statement, he's made clear he doesn't see a conflict of interest, despite the two sharing text messages. "Mr Fuller and I have a collegial, professional relationship. I describe him as a friend, and like I said in May, I consider all current and former Police Commissioners friends. My familiarity with Mr Fuller is from years of working together - including through the COVID pandemic – but it is not from socialising together. Mr Fuller and I do not have dinner at each other’s homes. We don’t play golf together. I don’t know the personal details of his life. I want to be clear about that because it is important that our professional relationship is not mischaracterised. The majority of the conversations Mr Fuller and I have are about matters relating to our former or current roles, or policing issues in general. What we have in common is dedication to service, to the community and keeping our people safe." Greens Senator David Shoebridge put to Commissioner Kershaw that he was involved in the early stages of the contracting process, before it was decided to award it to PwC. DS: Now you attended a meeting on the 28th of July 2022. Where you, (other staff) Mick Fuller in his position as PwC partner and other members of the PwC team... and the purpose of the meeting was said to be an introductory meeting to outline the identified need to undertake a comprehensive independent review of the AFPs delivery of policing services to the ACT government' and then this informed PwC is consideration of whether they had the capability to undertake the work and would submit a formal quote, you say that? RK: Yes. DS: Is that an accurate reflection of the meeting from your memory? RK: It was important to understand that they had had the capability to undertake that work given the importance of ACT policing, in particular challenges that they have been facing. like a lot of police forces across Australia (answer goes on). DS: Commissioner, you were in the pre contract meeting with PwC when there was a pre contract meeting, and you were there, working through with them, whether or not they got the contract? RK: I was understanding whether they had the capability. I was there, yes. The hearing continues.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AFP boss questioned on links to consulting firm PwC

featuredLink.title: 'Terrible leak': Texts between AFP commissioner and PwC partner raise questions over conflict of interest on contract

children.content: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw is facing tough questions about his links to former NSW Police Commissioner Mick Fuller - who went on to be a partner at consulting firm PwC and lead a lucrative $794,000 contract to review policing in the ACT.
In his opening statement, he's made clear he doesn't see a conflict of interest, despite the two sharing text messages.
"Mr Fuller and I have a collegial, professional relationship.
I describe him as a friend, and like I said in May, I consider all current and former Police Commissioners friends.
My familiarity with Mr Fuller is from years of working together
- including through the COVID pandemic –
but it is not from socialising together.
Mr Fuller and I do not have dinner at each other’s homes. We don’t play golf together.
I don’t know the personal details of his life.
I want to be clear about that because it is important that our professional relationship is not mischaracterised.
The majority of the conversations Mr Fuller and I have are about matters relating to our former or current roles, or policing issues in general.
What we have in common is dedication to service, to the community and keeping our people safe."
Greens Senator David Shoebridge put to Commissioner Kershaw that he was involved in the early stages of the contracting process, before it was decided to award it to PwC.

children.content: Reece Kershaw, AFP Commissioner
(ABC)

DS: Now you attended a meeting on the 28th of July 2022. Where you, (other staff) Mick Fuller in his position as PwC partner and other members of the PwC team... and the purpose of the meeting was said to be an introductory meeting to outline the identified need to undertake a comprehensive independent review of the AFPs delivery of policing services to the ACT government' and then this informed PwC is consideration of whether they had the capability to undertake the work and would submit a formal quote, you say that?
RK: Yes.
DS: Is that an accurate reflection of the meeting from your memory?
RK:

It was important to understand that they had had the capability to undertake that work given the importance of ACT policing, in particular challenges that they have been facing. like a lot of police forces across Australia (answer goes on).
DS: Commissioner, you were in the pre contract meeting with PwC when there was a pre contract meeting, and you were there, working through with them, whether or not they got the contract?
RK:
I was understanding whether they had the capability. I was there, yes.
The hearing continues.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Canadian province of Alberta has withdrawn its support for a bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games, citing overwhelming costs. The decision is another blow for the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) after the Canadian city of Hamilton (which hosted the inaugural Games in 1930) suspended its bid and Australia's Victorian government last month withdrew as host of the 2026 Games due to projected cost overruns. The Alberta bid was scuttled for similar reasons, Reuters reports. "We promised to remain transparent with Albertans about the costs of hosting international sporting events and clearly demonstrating a return on our investment for the people and communities of Alberta," wrote Mackenzie Blyth, press secretary to the Minister of Tourism and Sports Joseph Schow in an email to CBC. "In the case of the 2030 Commonwealth Games, the numbers just didn't add up for our government to commit taxpayer's money with the games estimated to cost $CA2.68 billion ($3.1 billion)."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'The numbers didn't add up': Canadian province withdraws bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games

props.alt: A Canadian female athlete walks and smiles next to someone carrying a large Canadian flag, during a Commonwealth Games ceremony

children.content: (AP: Kirsty Wigglesworth)
The Canadian province of Alberta has withdrawn its support for a bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games, citing overwhelming costs.

The decision is another blow for the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) after the Canadian city of Hamilton (which hosted the inaugural Games in 1930) suspended its bid and Australia's Victorian government last month withdrew as host of the 2026 Games due to projected cost overruns.
The Alberta bid was scuttled for similar reasons, Reuters reports.

"We promised to remain transparent with Albertans about the costs of hosting international sporting events and clearly demonstrating a return on our investment for the people and communities of Alberta," wrote Mackenzie Blyth, press secretary to the Minister of Tourism and Sports Joseph Schow in an email to CBC.
"In the case of the 2030 Commonwealth Games, the numbers just didn't add up for our government to commit taxpayer's money with the games estimated to cost $CA2.68 billion ($3.1 billion)."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AFP Commissioner Reece Kershaw has sought to dispute suggestions he should have declared a conflict of interest over his "friendship" with senior PwC partner Mick Fuller when meeting to discuss a contract. The AFP is facing questions over a $790,000 contract with PwC, over which Kershaw and former New South Wales Police Commissioner Mick Fuller met, before it was awarded without public tender. Text messages obtained by Greens senator David Shoebridge under freedom of information reveal repeated conversations between the pair, including references to "leaks". Kershaw says while he considers Fuller a friend, the relationship is professional. "Mr Fuller and I do not have dinner at each other's homes, we do not play golf together and I don't know the personal details of his life," he says. "I want to be clear about that because it is important that our professional relationship is not miscategorised." You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AFP boss disputes he should have declared conflict of interest over 'friendship' with PwC partner

featuredLink.title: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner Kershaw rubbishes suggestions he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

props.alt: A WhatsApp screenshot next to a photo of AFP commissioner Reece Kershaw and former NSW police commissioner Mick Fuller at a press conference

children.content: (AAP: Lukas Coch/Australian Federal Police)

AFP Commissioner Reece Kershaw has sought to dispute suggestions he should have declared a conflict of interest over his "friendship" with senior PwC partner Mick Fuller when meeting to discuss a contract.
The AFP is facing questions over a $790,000 contract with PwC
, over which Kershaw and former New South Wales Police Commissioner Mick Fuller met, before it was awarded without public tender.
Text messages obtained by Greens senator David Shoebridge under freedom of information
reveal repeated conversations between the pair, including references to "leaks"
Kershaw says while he considers Fuller a friend, the relationship is professional.
"Mr Fuller and I do not have dinner at each other's homes, we do not play golf together and I don't know the personal details of his life," he says.
"I want to be clear about that because it is important that our professional relationship is not miscategorised."
You can read more on this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police in the New Zealand city of Auckland are investigating a shooting which has left two people in a critical condition. Officers say the incident took place at around 11.30pm on Thursday night, on Queen Street in the city's CBD. Detective Senior Sergeant Craig Bolton says a small group of people started fighting before one offender pulled out a firearm and fired a number of shots. Police say one person has a gunshot wound to the head and another has a gunshot wound to the abdomen. "We believe that this was an isolated incident and there is no ongoing risk to the community," Detective Senior Sergeant Bolton says. "Police have zero tolerance for violence in public places, especially where firearms are used, and are working to hold the offenders to account. "We are following positive lines of enquiry and as part of the ongoing investigation, we ask anyone with information to come forward." The incident comes after a deadly shooting at a construction site in Auckland last month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two people critical after second Auckland shooting in a month

children.content: Police in the New Zealand city of Auckland are investigating a shooting which has left two people in a critical condition.
Officers say the incident took place at around 11.30pm on Thursday night, on Queen Street in the city's CBD.
Detective Senior Sergeant Craig Bolton says
a small group of people started fighting before one offender pulled out a firearm and fired a number of shots
Police say one person has a gunshot wound to the head and another has a gunshot wound to the abdomen.
"We believe that this was an isolated incident and there is no ongoing risk to the community," Detective Senior Sergeant Bolton says.
"Police have zero tolerance for violence in public places, especially where firearms are used, and are working to hold the offenders to account.
"We are following positive lines of enquiry and as part of the ongoing investigation, we ask anyone with information to come forward."
The incident comes after
a deadly shooting at a construction site in Auckland
last month.
